text: 3) stress that Federal Reserve policy was notthe source of the recovery from the Depression either. They state: "In theperiod under consideration [1933—1941), the Federal Reserve System madeessentially no attempt to alter the quantity of high—powered money by usingeither of the two instruments which had been its major reliance up to 1933W[1963, p. 511). While they are clearly aware that other developments, inparticular New Deal gold policy, led to a rise in the money supply during themid—1930s, Friedman and Schwartz appear to be so intent on castigating theFederal Reserve for its inaction that this monetary expansion receivesrelatively little attention.The emphasis that these early scholars place on policy inaction andineffectiveness may have led modern economists to assume that conventionalaggregate demand stimulus could not have mattered in the recovery from theGreat Depression.
